elements.content: We report the design and synthesis of two metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with permanent porosity, MOF-818 and MOF-919, using a small ditopic organic linker, 1H-pyrazole-4-carboxylic acid (H2PyC), 0.4 nm in length. Three mesoporous cages of unprecedented polyhedra are identified in these MOFs, a wuh cage in MOF-818 and yys and liu cages in MOF-919, with diameters of 3.8, 4.9, and 6.0 nm, respectively. The ditopic H2PyC linker functions as the edge in the structure, while two types of metal-containing second building units (SBUs) function as the vertices. 28 vertices are present in the wuh cage; 50 in the yys cage; and 70 in the liu cage. Systematic analysis of these cages along with other mesoporous cages in supramolecules and MOFs constructed by ditopic linkers reveals that the extension of cage size is dictated by both the number and connectivity of the vertices. The increase in cage size is proportional to the number of vertices, while the growth rate is determined by their connectivity. The reduction in connectivity is found to be an effective way to create large cages. All three cages in this report are constructed by three-connecting (3-c) vertices and two-connecting (2-c) vertices. This [2-c, 3-c] connectivity represents the least connectivity required for the construction of cages and the most effective one for cage size expansion. The largest cage, liu, exhibits a cage size to linker size ratio of 15, outstanding in supramolecules and MOFs. MOF-818 is stable in water with a wide pH range (pH = 2–12), and the wuh cage is big enough for the inclusion of biomolecules such as vitamin B12 and insulin.

elements.content: Large open cages constructed by molecular building blocks are highly desirable in supramolecular and reticular chemistry. Recently, the increase in cage size from micropore (<2 nm) to mesopore (2–50 nm) in supramolecules and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) allows for the introduction of large guests into the cages, thus extending their application from the storage and separation of gases to catalysis, drug delivery, and inclusion of biomolecules. The development of topological analysis and prediction also promotes the design and synthesis of structures with mesoporous cages. In general, these molecule-based cages can be described as either individual zero-dimensional (0D) polyhedra in the case of supramolecules or extended polyhedra in three-dimensional networks (3D nets) in MOFs, where the basic units in both cases are edges and vertices. In the cages constructed by the simplest ditopic organic linkers, the linkers function as the edges, where the metal-containing second building units (SBUs) function as the vertices. The increase of cage size can be achieved by extending the edge or increasing the number of vertices in the polyhedra. The former approach was be carried out by extending the length of organic linkers, thus leading to the precise control of cage size without altering the underlying polyhedra, while the latter one introduces more metal-containing SBUs in the cages, resulting in enrichment in the variety of polyhedra. The connectivity of vertices in the polyhedra, however, has received much less attention in previous studies, where systematic analysis is lacking. Here, we show that the connectivity of vertices is a critical parameter for the construction of large molecular cages. We find that, when the connectivity is reduced, larger polyhedra are formed with the same number of vertices. Thus, it is possible to use even a single type of small organic linker for the construction of extremely large molecular cages. This is demonstrated here by the creation of three mesoporous cages of unprecedented polyhedra, wuh, yys, and liu, in two new MOFs, MOF-818 and MOF-919, with spn and moo 3D nets, respectively, by a small linker, 1H-pyrazole-4-carboxylic acid (H2PyC), 0.4 nm in length. The largest cage, liu, is composed of 70 vertices, with permanent porosity and an internal pore size of 6.0 nm, 15 times that of the linker, which is outstanding in both supramolecules and MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Large open cages constructed by molecular building blocks are highly desirable in supramolecular and reticular chemistry. Recently, the increase in cage size from micropore (<2 nm) to mesopore (2-50 nm) in supramolecules and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) allows for the introduction of large guests into the cages, thus extending their application from the storage and separation of gases to catalysis, drug delivery, and inclusion of biomolecules. The development of topological analysis and prediction also promotes the design and synthesis of structures with mesoporous cages. In general, these molecule-based cages can be described as either individual zero-dimensional (0D) polyhedra in the case of supramolecules or extended polyhedra in three-dimensional networks (3D nets) in MOFs, where the basic units in both cases are edges and vertices. In the cages constructed by the simplest ditopic organic linkers, the linkers function as the edges, where the metal-containing second building units (SBUs) function as the vertices. The increase of cage size can be achieved by extending the edge or increasing the number of vertices in the polyhedra. The former approach was be carried out by extending the length of organic linkers, thus leading to the precise control of cage size without altering the underlying polyhedra, while the latter one introduces more metal-containing SBUs in the cages, resulting in enrichment in the variety of polyhedra. The connectivity of vertices in the polyhedra, however, has received much less attention in previous studies, where systematic analysis is lacking. Here, we show that the connectivity of vertices is a critical parameter for the construction of large molecular cages. We find that, when the connectivity is reduced, larger polyhedra are formed with the same number of vertices. Thus, it is possible to use even a single type of small organic linker for the construction of extremely large molecular cages. This is demonstrated here by the creation of three mesoporous cages of unprecedented polyhedra, wuh, yys, and liu, in two new MOFs, MOF-818 and MOF-919, with spn and moo 3D nets, respectively, by a small linker, 1H-pyrazole-4-carboxylic acid (H2PyC), 0.4 nm in length. The largest cage, liu, is composed of 70 vertices, with permanent porosity and an internal pore size of 6.0 nm, 15 times that of the linker, which is outstanding in both supramolecules and MOFs.

elements.content: The three new cages are studied alongside other cages in supramolecules and 3D MOFs (). All cages summarized here are composed of vertices linked by a ditopic organic linker, where the length of the linker is normalized to outline the impact of connectivity on cage size. For the first time, the connectivity of vertices in the polyhedra is systematically studied and leads to the discovery of two general principles: (1) the size of cage is proportional to the number of vertices, when the connectivity remains the same (A and Table S1, Supporting Information (SI)); (2) the growth of the cage size is dictated by the connectivity of the compositional vertices in the polyhedra (), where larger cages can be achieved by reducing the connectivity of the vertices in the polyhedra with the same number of vertices. The synthesis of three new cages here, wuh, yys, and liu, represents a good example of the compositional vertices exhibiting the minimum connectivity [2-c, 3-c] for the construction of polyhedra. This explains the fastest growth rate of their sizes among all molecular cages synthesized so far (); therefore, the combination of 3- and 2-connectivity stands as a promising method for the further extension in MOFs and supramolecules.

elements.content: (A) Correlation between the polyhedra size and the number of vertices in the polyhedra. (B) Topological illustration of polyhedra classified by their connectivity in both 0D molecular cages in supramolecular chemistry and 3D extended cages in MOFs. Red dots represent polyhedra composed of 2-c and 3-c vertices, blue dots 3-c vertices, green dots 3-c and 4-c vertices, and black dots 4-c vertices, respectively. Larger polyhedra exist with a large number of 3-c vertices. In order to provide a clear comparison, these larger polyhedra are listed in the SI. These results do not alter the clear trend that larger polyhedra are achieved with less connectivity of the vertices when the number is almost the same.

elements.content: ZrOCl2·8H2O (42.5 mg), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (124.0 mg), H2PyC (32.5 mg), and trifluoroacetic acid (120 μL) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 10 h to yield blue crystals after cooling to room temperature. The as-synthesized MOF-818 crystals were immersed in DMF for 3 days, during which the solvent exchange was performed five times using fresh DMF. This was followed by solvent exchange with acetone for 3 days, three times per day. The acetone in the pores of the MOF sample was removed by supercritical CO2 to give activated MOF-818. In the supercritical CO2 process, the sample was exchanged with fresh liquid CO2 seven times, with a duration of 15 min each time. Then the system was heated to 35 °C to reach a supercritical condition (typically 1200 psi) and held for 1 h, followed by slow release of CO2. The activated MOF-818 samples were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h and refilled with N2 for storage.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Activation of MOF-818

ZrOCl2⋅8H2O (42.5 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (124.0 mg), H2PyC (32.5 mg), and trifluoroacetic acid (120 μL) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 10 h to yield blue crystals after cooling to room temperature. The as-synthesized MOF-818 crystals were immersed in DMF for 3 days, during which the solvent exchange was performed five times using fresh DMF. This was followed by solvent exchange with acetone for 3 days, three times per day. The acetone in the pores of the MOF sample was removed by supercritical CO2 to give activated MOF-818. In the supercritical CO2 process, the sample was exchanged with fresh liquid CO2 seven times, with a duration of 15 min each time. Then the system was heated to 35 °C to reach a supercritical condition (typically 1200 psi) and held for 1 h, followed by slow release of CO2. The activated MOF-818 samples were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h and refilled with N2 for storage.

elements.content: For the synthesis of MOF-919-Fe, FeCl3·6H2O (35.5 mg), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (114.5 mg), and H2PyC (54.0 mg) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of DMF by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 12 h to yield green crystals after cooling to room temperature. Similarly, for the synthesis of MOF-919-Sc, ScCl3·6H2O (76.2 mg), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (135.6 mg), and H2PyC (34.8 mg) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of DMF by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 15 h to yield green crystals after cooling to room temperature. For the synthesis of MOF-919-Al, AlCl3·6H2O (43.1 mg), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (207.1 mg), H2PyC (39.0 mg), and trifluoroacetic acid (50 μL) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of DMF by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 10 h to yield blue crystals after cooling to room temperature. The activation procedures for all MOF-919-Fe, MOF-919-Sc, and MOF-919-Al were identical. The as-synthesized MOF-919 crystals were immersed in DMF for 3 days, during which the solvent exchange was performed five times using fresh DMF. This was followed by solvent exchange with ethanol for 3 days, three times per day. The solvent-exchanged MOF-919 samples were dried under vacuum at room temperature for 2 h and then at 150 °C for 12 h to achieve activated MOF-919.

Synthesis and Activation of MOF-919

For the synthesis of MOF-919-Fe, FeCl3⋅6H2O (35.5 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (114.5 mg), and H2PyC (54.0 mg) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of DMF by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 12 h to yield green crystals after cooling to room temperature. Similarly, for the synthesis of MOF-919-Sc, ScCl3⋅6H2O (76.2 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (135.6 mg), and H2PyC (34.8 mg) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of DMF by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 15 h to yield green crystals after cooling to room temperature. For the synthesis of MOF-919-Al, AlCl3⋅6H2O (43.1 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (207.1 mg), H2PyC (39.0 mg), and trifluoroacetic acid (50 μL) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of DMF by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 10 h to yield blue crystals after cooling to room temperature. The activation procedures for all MOF-919-Fe, MOF-919-Sc, and MOF-919-Al were identical. The as-synthesized MOF-919 crystals were immersed in DMF for 3 days, during which the solvent exchange was performed five times using fresh DMF. This was followed by solvent exchange with ethanol for 3 days, three times per day. The solvent-exchanged MOF-919 samples were dried under vacuum at room temperature for 2 h and then at 150 °C for 12 h to achieve activated MOF-919.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using both a lab-based and a synchrotron X-ray source. A Rigaku Smartlab 9 kW X-ray diffractometer with copper target Kα1 (λ = 1.540 56 Å) was used to collect the PXRD data of all these MOFs in both Bragg–Brentano (BB) and transmission mode. The PXRD data for Rietveld refinement were collected at beamline BL14B1 in transmission mode with λ = 1.2398 Å at Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). Two-dimensional small-angle X-ray scattering (2D-SAXS) was measured on a Rigaku 3.5 m NANOPIX system. The samples in all the X-ray diffraction/scattering measurements were directly exposed to air due to their chemical stability. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images and electron diffraction patterns were collected on a JEOL JEM-2100 Plus with a LaB6 electron source. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were obtained by a FEI Verios 460 at 0.5 kV at various magnifications. Elemental analysis of the activated MOF samples was performed by an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrum instrument (Leeman Laboratories Prodigy7, USA). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of MOFs was performed on a TA Instruments Q-500 series thermal gravimetric analyzer with samples held in aluminum oxide pans in a continuous nitrogen flow atmosphere. N2 adsorption of activated MOFs was measured on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 automatic volumetric instrument. X-ray adsorption spectra (XAS) of MOFs were collected at beamline BL08U at SSRF. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of MOFs was done on a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. Infrared (IR) spectra of MOFs were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet NEXUS IR spectrometer. Detailed characterization conditions are provided in the SI.

elements.content: The connectivity of vertices in polyhedra for both supramolecules and MOFs is defined by the number of edges (x) joining at the vertices within the polyhedra and marked as x-c. This is different from the connectivity of vertices in the 3D nets in the topological analysis of MOFs, where all edges linking to the vertices are counted. For example, in the case of MOF, the zinc oxide SBUs are linked to six edges in 3D nets, but only three edges within a single cubic polyhedron; thus the connectivity of this SBU as vertices in a polyhedron is 3-c, instead of 6-c (B). In the case of polyhedra constructed by multiple types of vertices, their connectivity is listed as combinations. For example, the ada cage in ZIF-23 contains two types of vertices with different connectivity, 2-c and 3-c; thus the connectivity of these polyhedra is represented as [2-c, 3-c] (B). The extraction of polyhedra from 3D nets of MOFs makes them comparable to isolated polyhedra in supramolecules. The sizes of polyhedra are plotted against the number of their compositional vertices, where the size of the edge is normalized to provide a fair comparison. A presents selected supramolecular cages and 3D extended cages in MOFs for the clear illustration of principles regarding the connectivity of vertices, while a complete plot is provided in Figure S3, SI, revealing the same trend. The actual sizes of these cages in their crystal structures are also provided and compared in Figures S1 and S2, SI.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Systematical Analysis on the Connectivity of Vertices for the Construction of Molecular Base Cages

The connectivity of vertices in polyhedra for both supramolecules and MOFs is defined by the number of edges (x) joining at the vertices within the polyhedra and marked as x-c. This is different from the connectivity of vertices in the 3D nets in the topological analysis of MOFs, where all edges linking to the vertices are counted. For example, in the case of MOF, the zinc oxide SBUs are linked to six edges in 3D nets, but only three edges within a single cubic polyhedron; thus the connectivity of this SBU as vertices in a polyhedron is 3-c, instead of 6-c (B). In the case of polyhedra constructed by multiple types of vertices, their connectivity is listed as combinations. For example, the ada cage in ZIF-23 contains two types of vertices with different connectivity, 2-c and 3-c; thus the connectivity of these polyhedra is represented as [2-c, 3-c] (B). The extraction of polyhedra from 3D nets of MOFs makes them comparable to isolated polyhedra in supramolecules. The sizes of polyhedra are plotted against the number of their compositional vertices, where the size of the edge is normalized to provide a fair comparison. A presents selected supramolecular cages and 3D extended cages in MOFs for the clear illustration of principles regarding the connectivity of vertices, while a complete plot is provided in Figure S3, SI, revealing the same trend. The actual sizes of these cages in their crystal structures are also provided and compared in Figures S1 and S2, SI.

elements.content: In the detailed analysis of the cages, there are two typical classes of materials differing in connectivity but showing the same trend. One class is supramolecules linked by 4-c vertices, marked in black dots in (A); the other one is zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), a type of MOF with zeolitic topologies and an imidazolate–Zn/Co coordination bond, where 3-c vertices are present, marked in blue dots in (A). Clear trends are observed for both connectivities, leading to the discovery of the first principle. The size of polyhedra increases as the number of vertices grows without altering the underlying connectivity (A). Specifically, the size of supramolecules increases in strict order from M6L12, M12L24, M24L48, M30L60, and M48L96, where the number of vertices is reflected in the subscript of M. The size of the cage in ZIF also increases in the order from sod, pau, lta, to ucb in ZIF-8, ZIF-10, ZIF-71, and ZIF-412, respectively, as the number of vertices grows from 24 to 144. The cages in other MOFs with the connectivity of 4-c or 3-c also fit into the corresponding trend. The MOF cage with [3-c, 4-c] connectivity, such as cage IV in FDM-3 and moz in ZIF-100, also exhibits a relatively large polyhedra size, as the number of vertices is 72 and 264, respectively, but negative curvature is observed at the external surface of the polyhedra. A similar trend is also observed in the MOFs with the connectivity of [2-c, 3-c], where polyhedra size increases from ada, wuh, yys, to liu in ZIF-23, MOF-818, and MOF-919 (last two), respectively. There are other predicted polyhedra with [2-c, 3-c] connectivity yet to be synthesized, such as cage 2 and cage 3 in mov and cage 3 and cage 4 in moo-a. These polyhedra are extremely large in size, and the number of vertices extends from 90 to 168. All examples above comply with the first principle. It is worth noting that, in the classes of the materials above, the structure directing factor is present within the organic linkers, while the construction of large cages in ZIFs relies on the steric repulsion between the adjacent linkers in the same ring. In contrast, the formation of wuh, yys, and liu cages with [2-c, 3-c] connectivity is governed by a different structure-directing factor, where neither the coordination angle within the linker nor repulsion between the adjacent linkers exists. These cages are formed strictly by the lowest symmetry principle in reticular chemistry, where the presence of two SBUs with different connectivity dictates the angles between the linkers. Detailed structure design can be found below.

elements.content: Another important trend is observed in between polyhedra with different connectivity. When the number of vertices is relatively the same, polyhedra with less connectivity usually exhibit a larger size. This comes as the second principle. Indeed, the sod cage in ZIF-8 is bigger than that of M24L48, both having 24 vertices in the polyhedra (B). The difference is in their connectivity, where less connectivity (3-c) is present in the sod cage, while there is 4-c for M24L48. Similarly, the polyhedra size increases gradually from M30L60, pau in ZIF-10, to the wuh cage in MOF-818, all three having vertices numbers between 28 and 32 (B and Table S1, SI). In general, the connectivity decreases from 4-c to 3-c to [2-c, 3-c] accordingly. Another example is the comparison between the yys cage in MOF-919 and the lta cage in ZIF-71 and M48L96, with the number of vertices in the range of 48 to 50 (B). The polyhedra size increases as the connectivity decreases from 4-c, to 3-c, to [2-c, 3-c] accordingly. The growth rate in polyhedra size for each connectivity can be estimated roughly by fitting the dots in Figure S3, SI. In general, reduced connectivity has a higher slope, indicating faster growth in the polyhedra size. [2-c, 3-c] is the minimum connectivity required for the construction of any polyhedra and also the one with the fastest growth rate for the creation of large molecule-based cages. When the actual cage size and linker size in the crystal structure are considered, the liu cage in this study exhibits the largest ratio of cage to linker size, 15, among all cages reported so far ( I). The geometric explanation for the second principle is that fewer vertices are required to construct a cage when the connectivity is low. Furthermore, it is more likely to form larger angles at the vertices when the connectivity is reduced, thus leading to a larger curvature (Figure S3, SI). Following these two principles, a series of cages with [2-c, 3-c] connectivity can be created including wuh, yys, and liu, along with other giant cages in 3D nets of spn, moo, num, oge, rra, nul, fav, mov, and moo-a. Here, the design and synthesis of MOF-818 and MOF-919 just provide a humble example.

Indeed, the sod cage in ZIF-8 is bigger than that of M24L48, both having 24 vertices in the polyhedra (B). The difference is in their connectivity, where less connectivity (3-c) is present in the sod cage, while there is 4-c for M24L48. Similarly, the polyhedra size increases gradually from M30L60, pau in ZIF-10, to the wuh cage in MOF-818, all three having vertices numbers between 28 and 32 (B and Table S1, SI). In general, the connectivity decreases from 4-c to 3-c to [2-c, 3-c] accordingly. Another example is the comparison between the yys cage in MOF-919 and the lta cage in ZIF-71 and M48L96, with the number of vertices in the range of 48 to 50 (B). The polyhedra size increases as the connectivity decreases from 4-c, to 3-c, to [2-c, 3-c] accordingly. The growth rate in polyhedra size for each connectivity can be estimated roughly by fitting the dots in Figure S3, SI. In general, reduced connectivity has a higher slope, indicating faster growth in the polyhedra size. [2-c, 3-c] is the minimum connectivity required for the construction of any polyhedra and also the one with the fastest growth rate for the creation of large molecule-based cages. When the actual cage size and linker size in the crystal structure are considered, the liu cage in this study exhibits the largest ratio of cage to linker size, 15, among all cages reported so far (  I). The geometric explanation for the second principle is that fewer vertices are required to construct a cage when the connectivity is low. Furthermore, it is more likely to form larger angles at the vertices when the connectivity is reduced, thus leading to a larger curvature (Figure S3, SI). Following these two principles, a series of cages with [2-c, 3-c] connectivity can be created including wuh, yys, and liu, along with other giant cages in 3D nets of spn, moo, num, oge, rra, nul, fav, mov, and moo-a. Here, the design and synthesis of MOF-818 and MOF-919 just provide a humble example.

elements.content: The construction of MOF-818 is based on spn topology selected from the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database. The 6-c nodes and 3-c nodes in the spn topology are achieved here by Zr-SBU and Cu-SBU, respectively. The Zr-SBU is formed by coordinating carboxylate in H2PyC with Zr6O8, while the Cu-SBU is formed by coordinating pyrazole in H2PyC with Cu, which is rare in MOFs (A). This allows us to simulate the crystal structure of MOF-818, where the largest cage wuh is present. The formula of MOF-818 is supposed to be [Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(OH)6(H2O)6]­[Cu3(μ3-O)­(μ-PyC)3(H2O)6]2 based on the charge balance and previous reports. The wuh cage is formed by 10 supertetrahedron (I) units sharing vertices (F). Each supertetrahedron (I) unit is composed of four Cu-SBUs and four Zr-SBUs (C). Within the wuh cage, both Cu-SBUs and Zr-SBUs function as the vertices to give a total number of 28 (G). All 12 Zr-SBUs correspond to 3-c vertices in the polyhedra, while 4 Cu-SBUs function as 3-c vertices and 12 Cu-SBUs as 2-c vertices. The size of the wuh cage and accurate angle at both types of vertices are given by the crystal structure of MOF-818 (Table S7, SI). The face symbol of the wuh cage is [124], where four 12-membered rings are present ().

elements.content: The crystal structure of MOF-818 is resolved by combining electron diffractions (ED) of the single crystal under TEM and refinement using the PXRD pattern collected at the synchrotron X-ray source. Prior to structure determination, MOF-818 samples were analyzed by SEM. The observed singular octahedra morphology of the crystals confirmed the phase purity of this MOF, with an average particle size of 400 nm (Figure S19, Supporting Information). The presence of sharp peaks in both ED and PXRD patterns reveal the high crystalline feature of this MOF (Figures S11, S12, and S21, SI). Detailed analysis of the ED pattern along the [001] and [111] directions revealed the following diffraction conditions: hkl: h + k = 2n, h + l = 2n, and k + l = 2n; 0hl: h + l = 4n; hhl: h + l = 2n; 00l: l = 4n, which narrowed down the possibilities to two cubic space groups: Fd3̅ and Fd3̅m. Here, we use the Fd3̅m space group with a higher symmetry for the structure refinement. The Rietveld refinement of synchrotron PXRD data against the simulated pattern of MOF-818 shows excellent fitness with satisfactory residue, R wp = 5.9% (D). This is further confirmed by the 2D-SAXS patterns of the same sample (A and B). Rietveld refinement of the SAXS profile covering q = 0.04 to 0.4 Å–1 [q = 4π sin­(θ)/λ] also shows low residue. Based on the crystal structure resolved, the size of the supertetrahedra is 1.8 nm, while the diameter and aperture of the wuh cage are 3.8 and 3.1 nm, respectively (3.7 and 3.0 nm, respectively, considering the van der Waals radii of the corresponding atoms) (). The size is measured by the distance between centers of the corresponding atoms in the structure.

elements.content: The construction of MOF-919 is based on moo topology chosen from the RCSR database. The 6-c nodes and 3-c nodes in the moo topology are achieved here by Fe/Sc/Al-SBU and Cu-SBU, respectively. The Fe/Sc/Al-SBU is formed by coordinating carboxylate in H2PyC with Fe3O/Sc3O/Al3O, while the Cu SBU is identical to that in MOF-818 (A). This allows us to simulate the crystal structure of MOF-919, where the large cage yys and liu polyhedra are present. The formula of MOF-919 is supposed to be [M3(μ3-O)­(OH)3]­[Cu3(μ3-O)­(μ-PyC)3(H2O)6]2 (M = Sc, Al, and Fe) based on the charge balance and previous reports. Each yys cage is formed by linking 20 supertetrahedra (E), where the supertetrahedron is constructed by four Fe/Sc/Al-SBUs and four Cu-SBUs (B). Each liu cage is formed by linking 28 supertetrahedra (H). Within the yys and liu cages, both Cu-SBUs and Fe/Sc/Al-SBUs function as the vertices to give a total number of 50 and 70, respectively. All 30 Fe/Sc/Al-SBUs correspond to 2-c vertices in the polyhedra and 20 Cu-SBUs function as 3-c vertices in the yys cage, while 42 Fe/Sc/Al-SBUs and 28 Cu-SBUs in the liu cage act as 2-c and 3-c vertices, respectively (F and I). The size of yys and liu cages and accurate angles at both types of vertices are given by the crystal structure of MOF-919 (Table S8, SI). The face symbol of the yys cage is [1012], where 12 10-member rings are present. The face symbol of the liu cage is [1012.124], where 12 10-membered rings and four 12-membered rings are present (). The observed singular octahedra morphology of the crystals confirmed the phase purity of MOF-919, with an average particle size of 4 μm (Figure S20, SI). The sharp peaks in the PXRD patterns obtained before and after activation indicate the high crystallinity of MOF-919 (H, S8, S9, and S12 to S14, SI). MOF-919 can be formed by linking Cu-SBUs with Fe-SBUs, Al-SBUs, and Sc-SBUs, to generate three iso-reticular structures, MOF-919-Fe, MOF-919-Al, and MOF-919-Sc, respectively. The PXRD pattern of MOF-919-Sc collected at the synchrotron X-ray source exhibits interpretable diffractions beyond q = 1.76 Å–1 (H and S15, SI). Rietveld refinement of the PXRD profile leads to the resolution of MOF-919-Sc, where the intensity and position of most diffraction peaks match well with those calculated on the basis of simulated structure with the space group of Fd3̅m. A relatively high residue, however, was generated (R wp = 23.2%). One reason is the huge number of atoms (116 000) in the large cubic unit cell [a = 116.6990(0) Å] and the large pore volume, where the influence of solvent molecules is not negligible. Another reason is the extremely low q values of the first few peaks (111, 220, 311, etc.), making the geometry and optics of the diffractometer critical for the collection of low -q peaks with accurate intensities. The optics of the synchrotron beamline designed for wide-angle X-ray diffraction is no longer suitable to give an accurate peak intensity at low q. This is reflected in the obvious deviation of the low-q peak intensity in comparison to that of the high-angle peak in the Rietveld refinement of the synchrotron PXRD data here. In light of this, we collected the 2D-SAXS patterns of the same sample to access accurate intensities of the low-q peaks. Rietveld refinement of the SAXS pattern showed less deviation from the simulated pattern, especially at the low-q region, and a smaller residue was achieved, R wp = 19.4%, even with a limited number of independent diffractions (E,F and S18, SI). The structure of MOF-919-Sc is further validated by the presence of two pore-filling steps corresponding to yys and liu cages at high P/P 0, details of which are discussed in the following section. Based on the crystal structure resolved, the size of the supertetrahedra (II) is 1.8 nm. The diameter and aperture of the yys cage are 4.9 and 2.0 nm, respectively (4.8 and 1.9 nm, respectively, considering the van der Waals radii of the corresponding atoms) (). The larger liu cage has two kinds of apertures: one, 2.0 nm, is the same as the aperture in the yys cage at the 10-membered ring, while the size of the other at the 12-membered ring replaced by the pore opening is 2.5 nm (2.4 nm considering the van der Waals radii of the corresponding atoms). The diameter of the liu cage is 6.0 nm (5.9 nm considering the van der Waals radii of the corresponding atoms) (G and H). The size is measured by the distance between centers of the corresponding atoms in the structure.

elements.content: Structures of both MOF-818 and MOF-919 are [3-c, 6-c] nets. The different topologies result from the different geometries of their SBUs. The Zr-SBUs in MOF-818 has a symmetry of 3̅m (D 3d ) with a staggered pattern (A), while the symmetry is 6̅m2 (D 3h ) for Fe/Sc/Al-SBUs in MOF-919, and it is in an eclipsed pattern (A). Combining these SBUs with the triangular SBU leads inevitably to spn and moo, respectively, as the simplest (minimal transitivity) possible nets.

The Zr-SBUs in MOF-818 has a symmetry of 3̅m (D 3d ) with a staggered pattern (A), while the symmetry is 6̅m2 (D 3h ) for Fe/Sc/Al-SBUs in MOF-919, and it is in an eclipsed pattern (A). Combining these SBUs with the triangular SBU leads inevitably to spn and moo, respectively, as the simplest (minimal transitivity) possible nets.

elements.content: Prior to the gas adsorption analysis, the solvent molecules in the pores were removed by degassing. The complete removal of solvent residues was confirmed by TGA, where no weight loss was observed before 280 °C for both MOF-818 and MOF-919 (Figures S22–S24, SI). The permanent porosity of these MOFs in guest-free form was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-818 is type IV, which is typical for mesoporous materials, and the starting point of the second step is observed at P/P 0 = 0.27. The pore distribution analysis based on the N2 adsorption isotherm using quenched solid state functional theory (QSDFT) showed there are one kind of mesopore with a width of 3.7 nm in MOF-818, which is in good agreement with its crystal structure (C). The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-919-Sc contains two steps with starting pressures of P/P 0 = 0.29 and 0.40, which is consistent with the sequential filling of yys and liu cages in MOF-919-Sc, respectively. QSDFT analysis of the N2 adsorption isotherm gives a pore distribution with sizes of 2.0, 3.9, and 6.0 nm, which is in good agreement with the crystal structure (G). There are no hysteresis loops observed in the N2 adsorptions of MOF-818 and MOF-919. This is because the increasing steps of the isotherms are below the limit of hysteresis of P/P 0 = 0.42 for N2 at 77 K. The calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc are 2050 and 2740 m2/g, respectively.

Characterizations of Porosity and Stability of MOFs

Prior to the gas adsorption analysis, the solvent molecules in the pores were removed by degassing. The complete removal of solvent residues was confirmed by TGA, where no weight loss was observed before 280 °C for both MOF-818 and MOF-919 (Figures S22-S24, SI). The permanent porosity of these MOFs in guest-free form was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-818 is type IV, which is typical for mesoporous materials, and the starting point of the second step is observed at P/P 0 = 0.27. The pore distribution analysis based on the N2 adsorption isotherm using quenched solid state functional theory (QSDFT) showed there are one kind of mesopore with a width of 3.7 nm in MOF-818, which is in good agreement with its crystal structure (C). The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-919-Sc contains two steps with starting pressures of P/P 0 = 0.29 and 0.40, which is consistent with the sequential filling of yys and liu cages in MOF-919-Sc, respectively. QSDFT analysis of the N2 adsorption isotherm gives a pore distribution with sizes of 2.0, 3.9, and 6.0 nm, which is in good agreement with the crystal structure (G). There are no hysteresis loops observed in the N2 adsorptions of MOF-818 and MOF-919. This is because the increasing steps of the isotherms are below the limit of hysteresis of P/P 0 = 0.42 for N2 at 77 K. The calculated Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc are 2050 and 2740 m2/g, respectively.

elements.content: Both MOF-818 and MOF-919 exhibit excellent chemical stabilities in air and humidity, reflected in the unaltered PXRD patterns and gas adsorption uptakes after exposure to air for a week (C and E). MOF-818 is also stable in aqueous solution with various pH values, as confirmed by PXRD studies. After being immersed in water, a HCl aqueous solution with pH = 2, and a NaOH aqueous solution with pH = 12 for 10 days, the PXRD of MOF-818 still matches well with the simulated one, indicating its high chemical stability (C and S27, SI). The large porosity and chemical stability of these MOFs make them ideally suited for the inclusion of large molecules in water. A common drug, vitamin B12 (VB12), with a size of 2.7 nm, and a natural protein, insulin, with a size of 3.4 nm, are used in the inclusion test (C, S38, and S41, SI). Both molecules exhibit sizes smaller than the opening of the wuh cage, and they are successfully introduced into this cage by immersion of MOFs in the aqueous solution of the corresponding guest molecules. The uptake of VB12 in MOF-818 and insulin in MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc are measured by ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) and fluorescent spectrophotometry, respectively (Figures S38 and S41, SI). The decrease in the fingerprint peak at 550 nm in the UV–vis spectra of the VB12 solution after immersion of MOFs confirmed the inclusion of VB12 (Figure S38, SI). Standard curves of various concentrations of VB12 were used to prove accurate uptake of VB12, and the calculated uptake is 4.4 nmol/mg. Similar experiments were performed for the inclusion of insulin in MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc, which showed a continuous decrease in the concentration of insulin. The calculated uptake of insulin was 2.8 nmol/mg and 3.79 nmol/mg for MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc, respectively, based on the standard curve (B). The inclusion of insulin was also reflected in the systematical variation of peak intensity in the PXRD pattern of MOF-818 and MOF-919, while adhesion on the crystal surface will not alter the intensity of the peaks (Figure S43 and S46, SI). A N2 adsorption isotherm was obtained on the MOF samples after inclusion. The uptake at relatively low P/P 0 (<0.02) remains nearly unaltered, while the uptake after pore filling decreases dramatically, confirming the inclusion of insulin into the mesoporous wuh cage (D).

The large porosity and chemical stability of these MOFs make them ideally suited for the inclusion of large molecules in water. A common drug, vitamin B12 (VB12), with a size of 2.7 nm, and a natural protein, insulin, with a size of 3.4 nm, are used in the inclusion test (C, S38, and S41, SI). Both molecules exhibit sizes smaller than the opening of the wuh cage, and they are successfully introduced into this cage by immersion of MOFs in the aqueous solution of the corresponding guest molecules. The uptake of VB12 in MOF-818 and insulin in MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc are measured by ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) and fluorescent spectrophotometry, respectively (Figures S38 and S41, SI). The decrease in the fingerprint peak at 550 nm in the UV-vis spectra of the VB12 solution after immersion of MOFs confirmed the inclusion of VB12 (Figure S38, SI). Standard curves of various concentrations of VB12 were used to prove accurate uptake of VB12, and the calculated uptake is 4.4 nmol/mg. Similar experiments were performed for the inclusion of insulin in MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc, which showed a continuous decrease in the concentration of insulin. The calculated uptake of insulin was 2.8 nmol/mg and 3.79 nmol/mg for MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc, respectively, based on the standard curve (B). The inclusion of insulin was also reflected in the systematical variation of peak intensity in the PXRD pattern of MOF-818 and MOF-919, while adhesion on the crystal surface will not alter the intensity of the peaks (Figure S43 and S46, SI). A N2 adsorption isotherm was obtained on the MOF samples after inclusion. The uptake at relatively low P/P 0 (<0.02) remains nearly unaltered, while the uptake after pore filling decreases dramatically, confirming the inclusion of insulin into the mesoporous wuh cage (D).

cln_elements.content: ZrOCl2·8H2O (42.5 mg), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (124.0 mg), H2PyC (32.5 mg), and trifluoroacetic acid (120 μL) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 10 h to yield blue crystals after cooling to room temperature. The as-synthesized MOF-818 crystals were immersed in DMF for 3 days, during which the solvent exchange was performed five times using fresh DMF. This was followed by solvent exchange with acetone for 3 days, three times per day. The acetone in the pores of the MOF sample was removed by supercritical CO2 to give activated MOF-818. In the supercritical CO2 process, the sample was exchanged with fresh liquid CO2 seven times, with a duration of 15 min each time. Then the system was heated to 35 °C to reach a supercritical condition (typically 1200 psi) and held for 1 h, followed by slow release of CO2. The activated MOF-818 samples were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h and refilled with N2 for storage.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Activation of MOF-818

ZrOCl2⋅8H2O (42.5 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (124.0 mg), H2PyC (32.5 mg), and trifluoroacetic acid (120 μL) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) by ultrasound in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 10 h to yield blue crystals after cooling to room temperature. The as-synthesized MOF-818 crystals were immersed in DMF for 3 days, during which the solvent exchange was performed five times using fresh DMF. This was followed by solvent exchange with acetone for 3 days, three times per day. The acetone in the pores of the MOF sample was removed by supercritical CO2 to give activated MOF-818. In the supercritical CO2 process, the sample was exchanged with fresh liquid CO2 seven times, with a duration of 15 min each time. Then the system was heated to 35 °C to reach a supercritical condition (typically 1200 psi) and held for 1 h, followed by slow release of CO2. The activated MOF-818 samples were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h and refilled with N2 for storage.

cln_elements.content: Prior to the gas adsorption analysis, the solvent molecules in the pores were removed by degassing. The complete removal of solvent residues was confirmed by TGA, where no weight loss was observed before 280 °C for both MOF-818 and MOF-919 (Figures S22–S24, SI). The permanent porosity of these MOFs in guest-free form was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-818 is type IV, which is typical for mesoporous materials, and the starting point of the second step is observed at P/P 0 = 0.27. The pore distribution analysis based on the N2 adsorption isotherm using quenched solid state functional theory (QSDFT) showed there are one kind of mesopore with a width of 3.7 nm in MOF-818, which is in good agreement with its crystal structure (C). The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-919-Sc contains two steps with starting pressures of P/P 0 = 0.29 and 0.40, which is consistent with the sequential filling of yys and liu cages in MOF-919-Sc, respectively. QSDFT analysis of the N2 adsorption isotherm gives a pore distribution with sizes of 2.0, 3.9, and 6.0 nm, which is in good agreement with the crystal structure (G). There are no hysteresis loops observed in the N2 adsorptions of MOF-818 and MOF-919. This is because the increasing steps of the isotherms are below the limit of hysteresis of P/P 0 = 0.42 for N2 at 77 K. The calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc are 2050 and 2740 m2/g, respectively.

Characterizations of Porosity and Stability of MOFs

Prior to the gas adsorption analysis, the solvent molecules in the pores were removed by degassing. The complete removal of solvent residues was confirmed by TGA, where no weight loss was observed before 280 °C for both MOF-818 and MOF-919 (Figures S22-S24, SI). The permanent porosity of these MOFs in guest-free form was confirmed by N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K. The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-818 is type IV, which is typical for mesoporous materials, and the starting point of the second step is observed at P/P 0 = 0.27. The pore distribution analysis based on the N2 adsorption isotherm using quenched solid state functional theory (QSDFT) showed there are one kind of mesopore with a width of 3.7 nm in MOF-818, which is in good agreement with its crystal structure (C). The N2 adsorption isotherm of MOF-919-Sc contains two steps with starting pressures of P/P 0 = 0.29 and 0.40, which is consistent with the sequential filling of yys and liu cages in MOF-919-Sc, respectively. QSDFT analysis of the N2 adsorption isotherm gives a pore distribution with sizes of 2.0, 3.9, and 6.0 nm, which is in good agreement with the crystal structure (G). There are no hysteresis loops observed in the N2 adsorptions of MOF-818 and MOF-919. This is because the increasing steps of the isotherms are below the limit of hysteresis of P/P 0 = 0.42 for N2 at 77 K. The calculated Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of MOF-818 and MOF-919-Sc are 2050 and 2740 m2/g, respectively.

cln_elements.content: (A) Correlation between the polyhedra size and the number of vertices in the polyhedra. (B) Topological illustration of polyhedra classified by their connectivity in both 0D molecular cages in supramolecular chemistry and 3D extended cages in MOFs. Red dots represent polyhedra composed of 2-c and 3-c vertices, blue dots 3-c vertices, green dots 3-c and 4-c vertices, and black dots 4-c vertices, respectively. Larger polyhedra exist with a large number of 3-c vertices. In order to provide a clear comparison, these larger polyhedra are listed in the SI. These results do not alter the clear trend that larger polyhedra are achieved with less connectivity of the vertices when the number is almost the same.

Rietveld refinement of experimental SAXS data (B) and synchrotron data of MOF-818 (D), where blue circles are experimental data, the red line is calculated data, the black line is the difference, and purple bars are Bragg positions (λ = 1.540 56 Å for SAXS data and 1.2398 Å for synchrotron data). (C) N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K for MOF-818 (inset, pore distribution based on N2 adsorption isotherms). (E) 2D SAXS image of MOF-919-Sc (λ = 1.540 56 Å). Rietveld refinement of experimental SAXS data (F) and synchrotron data of MOF-919-Sc (H), where blue circles are experimental data, the red line is calculated data, the black line is the difference, and purple bars are Bragg positions (λ = 1.540 56 Å for SAXS data and 1.2398 Å for synchrotron data). (G) N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K for MOF-919-Sc (inset, pore distribution based on N2 adsorption isotherms). (I) Comparison of the ratio between cage size and linker size of large cages in classical supramolecules and mesoporous MOFs. Cages created by both a ditopic organic linker (marked in red) and other types (marked in blue) are listed here. If there is more than one type of cage in the structure, only the largest cage is used here for comparison. The largest dimension of the linker is used to represent the linker size to provide a fair comparison. When multiple types of linkers were used, an average linker size is used, where the largest dimension of each linker is weighed by the linker ratios. Details are described in Table S2, SI.
